channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: War Brought Putin Closer to Africa. Now It’s Pushing Them Apart.
item.description: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia prepares to host African leaders at a summit, a collapsed grain deal and the uncertain fate of Wagner mercenaries have cast a shadow.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Sergei Chirikov
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin with heads of African countries at a summit in Sochi, Russia, in 2019.

item.title: Biden Orders U.S. to Share Evidence of Russian War Crimes With Hague Court
item.description: The step signals a major shift in American policy and ends months of resistance by Pentagon officials who feared setting a precedent that could pave the way for the court to prosecute U.S. troops.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Tuesday. In recent days, he ordered the government to begin sharing evidence of Russian war crimes with the International Criminal Court.

item.title: Here’s What Happened When Hunter Biden Went to Court With a Plea Deal
item.description: In just a few hours, Judge Maryellen Noreika exposes a gulf in understanding between the president’s son and prosecutors on an agreement they had spent weeks hashing out.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Hunter Biden appeared at the courthouse in the J. Caleb Boggs Federal Building in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday.

item.title: Fed Raises Rates After a Pause and Leaves Door Open to More
item.description: Federal Reserve officials lifted borrowing costs by a quarter-point after pausing in June. Rates could rise more, but the central bank is not ready to commit.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: Sinead O’Connor, Evocative and Outspoken Singer, Is Dead at 56
item.description: She broke out with the single “Nothing Compares 2 U,” then caused an uproar a few years later by ripping up a photo of Pope John Paul II on “S.N.L.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario and Joe Coscarelli
item.category: I Do Not Want What I Haven't Got (Album)
item.media:credit: Frans Schellekens/Redferns, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Sinead O’Connor performing in 1988. She rarely shrank from controversy, though it often came with consequences for her career.

item.title: The Bald Power of Sinead O’Connor
item.description: The Irish singer’s shaved head was as much a part of her identity and allure as her sound.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Independent Newspapers Ireland/Getty Images
item.media:description: Sinead O’Connor performing at the Olympic Ballroom in 1988.

item.title: Sinead O’Connor’s Life in Pictures
item.description: The Irish singer had an evocative voice and cast a powerful silhouette onstage.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: John Stoddart/Popperfoto via Getty Images
item.media:description: Sinead O’Connor in 1994, several years after she won a Grammy for “I Do Not Want What I Haven’t Got.”

item.title: Mitch McConnell Freezes Midsentence in News Conference at Capitol
item.description: The 81-year-old Senate Republican leader, who had a serious fall earlier this year, was temporarily unable to speak during a news conference, raising questions about his health and future.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell is supported by colleagues during his weekly news conference at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Giuliani Concedes He Made False Statements About Georgia Election Workers
item.description: Rudolph W. Giuliani said he still had “legal defenses” in a case brought by two election workers who said he had defamed them as he asserted that the 2020 election was marred by fraud.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: The defamation suit is only one of several legal problems Rudolph W. Giuliani faces.

item.title: Where Is Melania Trump Now?
item.description: The former first lady has mostly retreated from public view — and steered clear of the campaign trail — while her husband fights to return to the White House and faces increasing legal peril.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Katie Rogers
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:credit: James Devaney/GC Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: In her post-presidential life, Melania Trump has pursued what she could not get in the White House: a sense of privacy.

item.title: How and Why Illegal Border Crossings Have Dropped So Dramatically
item.description: The Biden administration’s new asylum policy, which a judge blocked this week, has contributed to a plunge in illegal border crossings at the southern U.S. border.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Julie Turkewitz and Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A migrant camp between the border walls that separate San Diego from Tijuana, Mexico, on May 11 when President Biden’s asylum changes took effect.

item.title: 101°F in the Ocean Off Florida: Was It a World Record?
item.description: Measuring and comparing sea surface temperatures is complex, but scientists agree on one thing: A high reading this week is bad news for wildlife.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Alfonso Duran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Just off the shore in Florida. Many parts of the country have broken or tied temperature records this month.

item.title: Blistering Heat Spreads to U.S. Midwest as Wildfire Smoke Lingers
item.description: Midwestern residents sweltered in the heat wave that has scorched the South and Southwest for many days.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Chase Castor for The New York Times
item.media:description: A construction worker used a tarpaulin as a makeshift shade on Tuesday at the River Market in Kansas City, Mo., where a heat advisory was in effect.

item.title: Why Won’t Simon Ateba Stop Shouting?
item.description: The Today News Africa gadfly has become a hero on the right, thanks to his confrontational behavior in the White House briefing room.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Bernstein
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Simon Ateba, center, wearing a purple tie.

item.title: Is Miami English, Heavily Influenced by Spanish, a Dialect?
item.description: A linguistics professor found that even Miamians who aren’t fluent in Spanish use or understand phrases that are direct translations.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Alfonso Duran for The New York Times
item.media:description: South Pointe Park in Miami Beach this month. People went, as many Miamians might say, irregardless of the heat.

item.title: Kevin Spacey Is Acquitted of Sexual Assault Charges
item.description: A British jury on Wednesday found the actor not guilty of nine charges.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Susannah Ireland/Reuters
item.media:description: “I am humbled by the outcome,” Kevin Spacey told reporters outside the courthouse on Wednesday.

item.title: At Congressional Hearing on UFOs, Lawmakers Press for Answers
item.description: Pentagon officials have said most reported incidents involved items like airborne trash, weather balloons and drones.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Grusch, center, a former intelligence official who worked with the Pentagon’s task force looking into unidentified aerial phenomena, testified about alleged U.F.O. materials at Wednesday’s hearing.

item.title: Looming Retraction Casts Shadow Over Ranga Dias and Study of Superconductors
item.description: Misconduct allegations are leading scientists to question the work of Ranga Dias, including his claimed discovery of a room-temperature superconductor.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Lauren Petracca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ranga P. Dias, a professor of mechanical engineering and physics at the University of Rochester in New York.

item.title: After Fatal Ship Fire, Newark Mayor Wants Special Port Unit
item.description: Mayor Ras J. Baraka said he had begun discussions with the Port Authority and Coast Guard about creating a special team to battle shipboard fires.
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGeehan
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Newark Fire Academy held a graduation ceremony on Wednesday. Nine graduates will work for the Newark Fire Department; the others will go to other departments in the region. The Newark fire chief said he intended to hire 50 new firefighters this year.

item.title: Democrats and Republicans Are Living in Different Worlds
item.description: How you view the crisis of men and boys — and whether you think there is one — is just one of the ways you reveal your political leanings.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times

item.title: In Israel, the Hobbling of the Supreme Court Is Just the Start
item.description: The right-wing coalition’s hobbling of the Supreme Court is just the start of a campaign against the country’s democratic foundations.
item.dc:creator: Adam Shinar
item.media:credit: Amir Cohen/Reuters
item.media:description: A protest near the Israeli Parliament in Jerusalem on Monday after lawmakers passed a bill restricting the courts.

item.title: Business Is Betting That Consumers Have Gotten Used to High Prices
item.description: Prices that go up don’t necessarily have to come down.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images by CSA Images/Getty Images

item.title: ‘Oppenheimer’ and the Siren Song of World-Ending Technology
item.description: The story is a warning. Will we heed it?
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph by Joe Raedle/Getty

item.title: When Will the Rate Hikes End?
item.description: Also, a new phase of Ukraine’s offensive. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Source: Federal Reserve. By Karl Russell
item.media:description: Note: The rate since December 2008 is the upper limit of the federal funds target range.

item.title: Bo Goldman, Oscar-Winning Screenwriter, Dies at 90
item.description: He was a struggling writer when he won an Academy Award for “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.” He won another for “Melvin and Howard.”
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.category: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (Movie)
item.media:credit: ABC Photo Archives/Disney, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The screenwriter Bo Goldman at the 1976 Academy Awards, accepting the award for his work on “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.”

item.title: White House Condemns Fox News Over Greg Gutfeld’s Holocaust Comments
item.description: In a debate over Florida’s African American history curriculum, Greg Gutfeld said Jews in Nazi concentration camps “had to be useful” to survive, remarks that the White House called “an obscenity.”
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Greg Gutfeld took over the 10 p.m. time slot at Fox News last week.

item.title: Video: Crane Partially Collapses in NYC Injuring 11
item.description: Nine civilians and two firefighters were hurt when the crane on 10th Avenue collapsed, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Lola Fadulu and Amanda Holpuch

item.title: This Hummus Holds Up After 800 Years
item.description: First written down in the 13th century, this recipe has an enduring simplicity — but no garlic.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan
item.media:credit: Chris Simpson for The New York Times. Food stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop stylist: Sophia Pappas.
